msContents.summary: Business letter describing land ceded by Tapotamon to Diogenes.

msItemStruct.note: Text is on one side only, 20 lines written with the fibers. Text mentions the village of Korobis.

Two hands, with the body perhaps written by a clerk followed by an endorsment by Heraclas, one of the senders. The first 13 lines plus brief signoff in hand 1 (unless the brief line starts the next section) and 6 lines in hand 2.
Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology, shelf B-37-A-1

supportDesc.support: 9.5 x 20cm. Papyrus is torn along the bottom (approximately 7 cm across) with a tear also on the right hand side at lines 10-13 (3 vertical cm) and smaller tears in the middle of the papyrus lines 17-19, but the text is complete. It appears to have been folded vertically, down the middle. Top and left margins fully intact; right and bottom margins partially intact.

provenance.p: Excavated by Grenfell and Hunt (1896-7) on behalf of the Egyptian Exploration Fund, and donated to the University Museum in return for its support (1901, Dr. Parrish Collection).

div.ab: Phanias, Heraclas, and Diogenes also called Hermaeus, officials employed in land distribution, to the agoranomi, greeting. Diogenes, son of Ptolemaeus, has had ceded to him by Tapotamon, the daughter of Ptolemaeus, son of Kolylis, acting with her guardian who is her grandson Plutarchus, son of Plutarchus, son of Plutarchus, in accordance with the terms of a contract executed this day, a square piece of allotment corn land ready for sowing, the property of Tapotamon, situated near the village of Korobis and forming part of the lot of Menoetius, in size 1 + 1/2 + 1/3 + 1/12 arourae. We therefore write to inform you. Farewell. (followed by the note by Heraclas) [Grenfell & Hunt]
